 Summary: 
 
 Nepete applied for Convention refugee status. An Immigration and Refugee Board determined that Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees excluded Nepete from seeking Convention refugee status. The Board further held that Nepete had failed to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution. Nepete applied for judicial review.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, dismissed the application.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Aliens - Topic 1330.5 
 
 Admission - Refugees - Where claimant has rights of nationals of country other than homeland (art. 1E) - Nepete, a citizen of Angola, claimed Convention refugee status - The Minister introduced a letter from the Czech Republic indicating that the Czech Republic authorities considered Nepete to have permanent resident status in the Czech Republic but that, due to the expiry of his re-entry visa, he could not automatically re-enter - An Immigration and Refugee Board concluded that Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees excluded Nepete from obtaining Convention refugee status, because he was entitled to some of the basic rights which attached to nationals of the Czech Republic - The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, affirmed the decision - The Minister had established that Article 1E applied - The burden shifted to Nepete to show that he did not enjoy the "rights and obligations" which belonged to nationals of the Czech Republic - There was no evidence that the Czech Republic would deny a re-entry visa.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.), refd to. [para. 18].  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Statutes Noticed: 
 
 United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, art. 1E [para. 7].  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Counsel: 
 
 Jack Martin, for the applicant; 
 
 Susan Nucci, for the respondent.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 Jack C. Martin, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant; 
 
 Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Heneghan, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, heard this application at Toronto, Ontario, on August 30, 2000, and delivered the following reasons for judgment on October 11, 2000.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>   <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 
    <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Heneghan, J. 
 : Mr. Firmino Domingos Nepete (the "Applicant") seeks judicial review of a decision of the Immigration and Refugee Board, Convention Refugee Determination Division ("Board) made on August 17, 1999. In its decision, the Board found that the Applicant is excluded from seeking convention refugee status and furthermore, that he had failed to demonstrate that he had a well-founded fear of persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[2] 
  The Applicant is a citizen of Angola. On October 25, 1994 he obtained a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. On November 26, 1997, he applied for admission into Canada as a convention refugee.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[3] 
  In his Personal Information Form ("PIF") the Applicant referred to the events which led him to leave Angola. He also referred to incidents upon which he relied to ground his fear of persecution in the Czech Republic and described those events, including discrimination in his efforts to find employment, harassment and two beatings, one of which required hospitalization.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[4] 
  In its decision, the Board concluded that the Applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution in Angola, based on his membership in a particular social group. In consequence, the Board found that the only country of reference for considering a convention refugee claim was the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[5] 
  The Board found that the evidence established that the Applicant is a permanent resident of the Czech Republic, holding a permanent residence permit valid until October 1999. The Board then went on to consider whether the Applicant falls within the ambit of Article 1E and consequently is precluded from obtaining convention refugee status in Canada.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[6] 
  The  
 Immigration Act 
 , R.S.C. s. 2(1) defines "refugee convention" as follows: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "s. 2(1) In this Act, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 'Refugee Convention' means any person who <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (a) by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (i) is outside the country of the person's nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country, or <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (ii) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of the person's former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, is unwilling to return to that country, and <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (b) has not ceased to be a Convention refugee by virtue of subsection (2), but does not include any person to whom the Convention does not apply pursuant to section E or F of Article 1 thereof, which sections are set out in the schedule to this Act; <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 
    <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "2(1) The following definitions apply in this Act.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 'Convention refugee' Any person: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 a) who, having a well-founded fear of being persecuted because of their race, religion, nationality, membership in a social group or political opinions: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (i) either is outside the country of nationality and cannot or, due to this fear, does not want to claim the protection of that country, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (ii) or, if he does not have a nationality and is outside the country in which he had his habitual residence, cannot or, because of this fear, does not want to return there;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (b) who has not lost his or her Convention refugee status under subsection (2). Excluded from this definition are persons exempted from the application of the Convention by sections E or F of the first article thereof, the text of which is reproduced in the annex to this law. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[7] 
  Article 1E, referenced in this definition, is included as part of the schedule to the  
 Immigration Act 
 , supra, and provides as follows:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "This Convention shall not apply to a person who is recognized by the competent authorities of the country in which he has taken residence as having the rights and obligations which are attached to the position of the nationality of that country. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 
    <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "Cette Convention ne sera pas applicable à une personne considérée par les autorités compétentes du pays dans lequel cette personne a établi sa résidence comme ayant les droits et les obligations attachés à la possession de la nationalité de ce pays. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[8] 
  In its decision, the Board addressed the issue whether the Applicant was entitled to some of the basic rights which attach to nationals of the Czech Republic, the country in which he has permanent resident status. The Board found that the Applicant was entitled to some of the basic rights which attach to nationals of that country. The Board concluded that the Applicant was excluded from obtaining convention refugee status in Canada, following application of Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[9] 
  In reaching its conclusion, the Board relied upon a letter received from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic in Montreal. This letter, dated July 13, 1999, was entered as exhibit R4 at the hearing before the Board. [see footnote 1] This letter, addressed to the Board, confirms that the Applicant had been granted a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic on October 29, 1994 for family reunion purposes, following his marriage with a Czech citizen on June 20, 1987. His status as a permanent resident was unaffected by his subsequent divorce on October 7, 1997.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[10] 
  The letter advises that the Applicant's permanent residence is still registered at a street address in the Czech Republic. Furthermore, this letter advises that due to the expiry of his re-entry visa, the Applicant cannot automatically re-enter the Czech Republic but must apply for a visa from that country.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[11] 
  The Board found that the onus lies upon the Applicant to officially advise the authorities in the Czech Republic that he wishes to retain his permanent resident status and to apply for a re-entry visa in order to return to that country. The Board applied the decision of this Court in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.). The Board relied on this decision as authority for the proposition that once prima facie evidence is adduced with respect to the status of permanent residence, the onus shifts to the claimant to demonstrate why he cannot obtain a re-entry visa. In the present case, the Board said it was not satisfied that the Applicant had discharged his onus in this regard.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[12] 
  In addition to considering the fact that the Applicant holds permanent resident status in the Czech Republic, at least according to the officials of that country, the Board considered that the Applicant had the right to work without restrictions in the Czech Republic. It appears that the Board relied upon this factor as well, in reaching its conclusion that the Applicant is excluded pursuant to Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[13] 
  The Board then went on to consider whether the Applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution in the Czech Republic which would displace the exclusionary effect of Article 1E. The Board found, after its review of the evidence, that the Applicant had not demonstrated a well-founded fear of persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[14] 
  The Board found that the incidents complained about by the Applicant amounted to discrimination but did not meet the standard of persecution. The Board ultimately concluded that the Applicant had not established a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of his race, in the Czech Republic. Accordingly, the Board concluded that the Applicant falls within the terms of Article 1E and is excluded from the convention refugee definition.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[15] 
  In his application for judicial review, the Applicant raised for several arguments. First, he argued that the burden is upon the Minister, not on him, to prove the elements underlying exclusion pursuant to Article 1E. Next, he argued that the Board misinterpreted the application of Article 1E by failing to appreciate that a national would not have to apply for re-entry to a country, submitting that without the right of return, he does not have the rights of a national. As part of this argument, the Applicant says it is misleading to suggest that he had initiated a cancellation of his permanent residence in the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[16] 
  Finally, the Applicant argued that the Board erred in law in its interpretation of "persecution" in the convention refugee definition when it found that the actions complained of in the Czech Republic did not amount to persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[17] 
  According to its reasons, the Board placed great reliance upon the letter dated July 13, 1999 from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic, Montreal Office. This letter clearly states that the Applicant does not have an automatic right of re-entry into the Czech Republic. The letter states:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "3. Due to expiry of the re-entry visa Mr. Nepete cannot automatically re-enter the Czech Republic - it means he has to apply for the Czech visa. In other words, he does not have an automatic right of re-entry to the Czech Republic." [see footnote 2]  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[18] 
   <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.) and  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , the Applicants' re-entry visa or travel documents had also expired at the time of the hearing, yet this Court found that that was not an impediment to exclusion under Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[19] 
  The hearing took place on July 15, 1999. The Board relied on the letter of July 13, 1999 and found that, as of that date, the Applicant was considered by the Czech authorities to have the status of a permanent resident, although he did not have an automatic right of re-entry to the Czech Republic due to the expiry of his re-entry visa.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[20] 
  In other cases, this Court has decided that Article 1E will apply, for exclusion purposes, even when an applicant does not enjoy the full rights of a national of another country. It is sufficient for the Respondent to show that the Czech Republic recognizes that the Applicant may apply for re-entry to the Czech Republic; see  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[21] 
  There is no dispute that the Respondent bears the burden of showing that Article 1E applies to exclude the authority. The point was addressed by Justice Rothstein in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , paragraph 11, where he said:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "At the very least, once the respondent put forward prima facie evidence that Article 1E applies the onus shifted to the applicant to demonstrate why, having destroyed her carte, she could not apply and obtain a new one. She did not do so. (Para. 11) <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[22] 
  In my opinion, the Respondent has met this burden by producing the letter dated July 13, 1999 from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic in Montreal. The burden then shifts to the Applicant, to show that he does not enjoy the "rights and obligations" which belong to the nationals of the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[23] 
  There is no evidence on the record to show that the Applicant would be denied a re-entry visa for the Czech Republic, although it is clear that he has no right to obtain such a visa. While it may seem inconsistent to say that recognition of permanent residence status can co-exist without a right of re-entry, that distinction has been recognized by the Court in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  and  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[24] 
  In the present case, the Board applied the decision in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , to the evidence before it. Its decision appears reasonable, having regard to the evidence and the prevailing law.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[25] 
  However, even if I were to find that Article 1E does not apply, this application for judicial review must fail.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[26] 
  The Board went on to consider the application for convention refugee status on its merits and found that the Applicant had failed to demonstrate that he had a well-founded fear of persecution in relation to the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[27] 
  This is clearly a matter of weighing the evidence and within the jurisdiction of the Board. In the absence of anything on the record to show that the Board misinterpreted the evidence or based its findings on irrelevant or extraneous matters or reached a conclusion in a capricious or perverse manner, there is no basis for interfering with the decision of the Board.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[28] 
  The application for judicial review is dismissed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[29] 
  At the request of Counsel, the parties will have seven days from receipt of these reasons to submit a question for certification.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Application dismissed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Editor: Gary W. McLaughlin/pdk  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Footnotes  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 1.Tribunal Record, page 629.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 2.Tribunal Record, supra  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 [End of document]

 Summary: 
 
 Nepete applied for Convention refugee status. An Immigration and Refugee Board determined that Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees excluded Nepete from seeking Convention refugee status. The Board further held that Nepete had failed to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution. Nepete applied for judicial review.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, dismissed the application.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

 Admission - Refugees - Where claimant has rights of nationals of country other than homeland (art. 1E) - Nepete, a citizen of Angola, claimed Convention refugee status - The Minister introduced a letter from the Czech Republic indicating that the Czech Republic authorities considered Nepete to have permanent resident status in the Czech Republic but that, due to the expiry of his re-entry visa, he could not automatically re-enter - An Immigration and Refugee Board concluded that Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees excluded Nepete from obtaining Convention refugee status, because he was entitled to some of the basic rights which attached to nationals of the Czech Republic - The Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, affirmed the decision - The Minister had established that Article 1E applied - The burden shifted to Nepete to show that he did not enjoy the "rights and obligations" which belonged to nationals of the Czech Republic - There was no evidence that the Czech Republic would deny a re-entry visa.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

 Heneghan, J., of the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, heard this application at Toronto, Ontario, on August 30, 2000, and delivered the following reasons for judgment on October 11, 2000.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>   <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[1] 
   
 Heneghan, J. 
 : Mr. Firmino Domingos Nepete (the "Applicant") seeks judicial review of a decision of the Immigration and Refugee Board, Convention Refugee Determination Division ("Board) made on August 17, 1999. In its decision, the Board found that the Applicant is excluded from seeking convention refugee status and furthermore, that he had failed to demonstrate that he had a well-founded fear of persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[2] 
  The Applicant is a citizen of Angola. On October 25, 1994 he obtained a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic. On November 26, 1997, he applied for admission into Canada as a convention refugee.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[3] 
  In his Personal Information Form ("PIF") the Applicant referred to the events which led him to leave Angola. He also referred to incidents upon which he relied to ground his fear of persecution in the Czech Republic and described those events, including discrimination in his efforts to find employment, harassment and two beatings, one of which required hospitalization.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[4] 
  In its decision, the Board concluded that the Applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution in Angola, based on his membership in a particular social group. In consequence, the Board found that the only country of reference for considering a convention refugee claim was the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[5] 
  The Board found that the evidence established that the Applicant is a permanent resident of the Czech Republic, holding a permanent residence permit valid until October 1999. The Board then went on to consider whether the Applicant falls within the ambit of Article 1E and consequently is precluded from obtaining convention refugee status in Canada.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[6] 
  The  
 Immigration Act 
 , R.S.C. s. 2(1) defines "refugee convention" as follows: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "s. 2(1) In this Act, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 'Refugee Convention' means any person who <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (a) by reason of a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or political opinion, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (i) is outside the country of the person's nationality and is unable or, by reason of that fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country, or <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (ii) not having a country of nationality, is outside the country of the person's former habitual residence and is unable or, by reason of that fear, is unwilling to return to that country, and <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (b) has not ceased to be a Convention refugee by virtue of subsection (2), but does not include any person to whom the Convention does not apply pursuant to section E or F of Article 1 thereof, which sections are set out in the schedule to this Act; <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 
    <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "2(1) The following definitions apply in this Act.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 'Convention refugee' Any person: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 a) who, having a well-founded fear of being persecuted because of their race, religion, nationality, membership in a social group or political opinions: <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (i) either is outside the country of nationality and cannot or, due to this fear, does not want to claim the protection of that country, <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (ii) or, if he does not have a nationality and is outside the country in which he had his habitual residence, cannot or, because of this fear, does not want to return there;  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 (b) who has not lost his or her Convention refugee status under subsection (2). Excluded from this definition are persons exempted from the application of the Convention by sections E or F of the first article thereof, the text of which is reproduced in the annex to this law. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[7] 
  Article 1E, referenced in this definition, is included as part of the schedule to the  
 Immigration Act 
 , supra, and provides as follows:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "This Convention shall not apply to a person who is recognized by the competent authorities of the country in which he has taken residence as having the rights and obligations which are attached to the position of the nationality of that country. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 
    <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "Cette Convention ne sera pas applicable à une personne considérée par les autorités compétentes du pays dans lequel cette personne a établi sa résidence comme ayant les droits et les obligations attachés à la possession de la nationalité de ce pays. <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[8] 
  In its decision, the Board addressed the issue whether the Applicant was entitled to some of the basic rights which attach to nationals of the Czech Republic, the country in which he has permanent resident status. The Board found that the Applicant was entitled to some of the basic rights which attach to nationals of that country. The Board concluded that the Applicant was excluded from obtaining convention refugee status in Canada, following application of Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[9] 
  In reaching its conclusion, the Board relied upon a letter received from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic in Montreal. This letter, dated July 13, 1999, was entered as exhibit R4 at the hearing before the Board. [see footnote 1] This letter, addressed to the Board, confirms that the Applicant had been granted a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic on October 29, 1994 for family reunion purposes, following his marriage with a Czech citizen on June 20, 1987. His status as a permanent resident was unaffected by his subsequent divorce on October 7, 1997.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[10] 
  The letter advises that the Applicant's permanent residence is still registered at a street address in the Czech Republic. Furthermore, this letter advises that due to the expiry of his re-entry visa, the Applicant cannot automatically re-enter the Czech Republic but must apply for a visa from that country.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[11] 
  The Board found that the onus lies upon the Applicant to officially advise the authorities in the Czech Republic that he wishes to retain his permanent resident status and to apply for a re-entry visa in order to return to that country. The Board applied the decision of this Court in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.). The Board relied on this decision as authority for the proposition that once prima facie evidence is adduced with respect to the status of permanent residence, the onus shifts to the claimant to demonstrate why he cannot obtain a re-entry visa. In the present case, the Board said it was not satisfied that the Applicant had discharged his onus in this regard.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[12] 
  In addition to considering the fact that the Applicant holds permanent resident status in the Czech Republic, at least according to the officials of that country, the Board considered that the Applicant had the right to work without restrictions in the Czech Republic. It appears that the Board relied upon this factor as well, in reaching its conclusion that the Applicant is excluded pursuant to Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[13] 
  The Board then went on to consider whether the Applicant has a well-founded fear of persecution in the Czech Republic which would displace the exclusionary effect of Article 1E. The Board found, after its review of the evidence, that the Applicant had not demonstrated a well-founded fear of persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[14] 
  The Board found that the incidents complained about by the Applicant amounted to discrimination but did not meet the standard of persecution. The Board ultimately concluded that the Applicant had not established a well-founded fear of persecution by reason of his race, in the Czech Republic. Accordingly, the Board concluded that the Applicant falls within the terms of Article 1E and is excluded from the convention refugee definition.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[15] 
  In his application for judicial review, the Applicant raised for several arguments. First, he argued that the burden is upon the Minister, not on him, to prove the elements underlying exclusion pursuant to Article 1E. Next, he argued that the Board misinterpreted the application of Article 1E by failing to appreciate that a national would not have to apply for re-entry to a country, submitting that without the right of return, he does not have the rights of a national. As part of this argument, the Applicant says it is misleading to suggest that he had initiated a cancellation of his permanent residence in the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[16] 
  Finally, the Applicant argued that the Board erred in law in its interpretation of "persecution" in the convention refugee definition when it found that the actions complained of in the Czech Republic did not amount to persecution.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[17] 
  According to its reasons, the Board placed great reliance upon the letter dated July 13, 1999 from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic, Montreal Office. This letter clearly states that the Applicant does not have an automatic right of re-entry into the Czech Republic. The letter states:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "3. Due to expiry of the re-entry visa Mr. Nepete cannot automatically re-enter the Czech Republic - it means he has to apply for the Czech visa. In other words, he does not have an automatic right of re-entry to the Czech Republic." [see footnote 2]  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[18] 
   <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (T.D.) and  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , the Applicants' re-entry visa or travel documents had also expired at the time of the hearing, yet this Court found that that was not an impediment to exclusion under Article 1E.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[19] 
  The hearing took place on July 15, 1999. The Board relied on the letter of July 13, 1999 and found that, as of that date, the Applicant was considered by the Czech authorities to have the status of a permanent resident, although he did not have an automatic right of re-entry to the Czech Republic due to the expiry of his re-entry visa.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[20] 
  In other cases, this Court has decided that Article 1E will apply, for exclusion purposes, even when an applicant does not enjoy the full rights of a national of another country. It is sufficient for the Respondent to show that the Czech Republic recognizes that the Applicant may apply for re-entry to the Czech Republic; see  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[21] 
  There is no dispute that the Respondent bears the burden of showing that Article 1E applies to exclude the authority. The point was addressed by Justice Rothstein in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , paragraph 11, where he said:  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 "At the very least, once the respondent put forward prima facie evidence that Article 1E applies the onus shifted to the applicant to demonstrate why, having destroyed her carte, she could not apply and obtain a new one. She did not do so. (Para. 11) <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[22] 
  In my opinion, the Respondent has met this burden by producing the letter dated July 13, 1999 from the Consulate General of the Czech Republic in Montreal. The burden then shifts to the Applicant, to show that he does not enjoy the "rights and obligations" which belong to the nationals of the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[23] 
  There is no evidence on the record to show that the Applicant would be denied a re-entry visa for the Czech Republic, although it is clear that he has no right to obtain such a visa. While it may seem inconsistent to say that recognition of permanent residence status can co-exist without a right of re-entry, that distinction has been recognized by the Court in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  and  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> .  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[24] 
  In the present case, the Board applied the decision in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , to the evidence before it. Its decision appears reasonable, having regard to the evidence and the prevailing law.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[25] 
  However, even if I were to find that Article 1E does not apply, this application for judicial review must fail.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[26] 
  The Board went on to consider the application for convention refugee status on its merits and found that the Applicant had failed to demonstrate that he had a well-founded fear of persecution in relation to the Czech Republic.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[27] 
  This is clearly a matter of weighing the evidence and within the jurisdiction of the Board. In the absence of anything on the record to show that the Board misinterpreted the evidence or based its findings on irrelevant or extraneous matters or reached a conclusion in a capricious or perverse manner, there is no basis for interfering with the decision of the Board.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[28] 
  The application for judicial review is dismissed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

[29] 
  At the request of Counsel, the parties will have seven days from receipt of these reasons to submit a question for certification.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  
 Application dismissed.  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>

statutes: United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, art. 1E
legal_issues: Determining the applicability of an exclusion clause to refugee status based on recognition of rights and obligations in a country of residence.
Establishing the evidentiary burden and standard of proof regarding the enjoyment of rights equivalent to those of nationals in a country of residence for the purpose of refugee status determination.
Assessing whether the lack of an automatic right of re-entry to a country of residence impacts the determination of rights and obligations for refugee status exclusion.
Evaluating the sufficiency of evidence to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution required for refugee status.
Defining the threshold for 'persecution' in the context of a refugee claim.
Determining the appropriate standard of review for a decision regarding refugee status and the scope of judicial review of administrative findings of fact.
factual_background: An individual, Firmino Domingos Nepete, applied for Convention refugee status in Canada.
Nepete is a citizen of Angola.
Nepete obtained a permanent residence permit in the Czech Republic in 1994, based on family reunification following marriage to a Czech citizen.
Nepete applied for admission to Canada in 1997, claiming refugee status.
Nepete cited events in Angola and incidents in the Czech Republic (discrimination, harassment, and physical assault requiring hospitalization) as grounds for his claim.

The Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) determined that Nepete had a well-founded fear of persecution in Angola but considered the Czech Republic as the relevant country for assessing his refugee claim.
The IRB considered a letter from the Czech Republic confirming Nepete’s permanent resident status but noting his re-entry visa had expired, preventing automatic re-entry.

The IRB concluded that Nepete was excluded from seeking refugee status under Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, as he was considered to have rights associated with Czech nationals.
The IRB also found that Nepete had not demonstrated a well-founded fear of persecution in the Czech Republic.
Nepete sought judicial review of the IRB’s decision.

Applicants: The Minister bears the burden to prove the elements underlying exclusion pursuant to Article 1E.

The Board misinterpreted Article 1E by failing to appreciate that a national would not have to apply for re-entry to a country, and without the right of return, he does not have the rights of a national.
It is misleading to suggest that the Applicant initiated a cancellation of his permanent residence in the Czech Republic.
The Board erred in law in its interpretation of “persecution” in the convention refugee definition when it found that the actions complained of in the Czech Republic did not amount to persecution.
Respondents: Article 1E of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees applies, excluding the Applicant from seeking refugee status because he is recognized by the Czech Republic as having rights and obligations attached to the position of nationality.
The Applicant is a permanent resident of the Czech Republic and has the right to work without restrictions there.
Once prima facie evidence of Article 1E’s application was presented, the onus shifted to the Applicant to demonstrate why he could not obtain a re-entry visa to the Czech Republic.
There is no evidence that the Czech Republic would deny the Applicant a re-entry visa.

court_analysis: The central issue was whether Nepete was excluded from claiming refugee status under Article 1E of the UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, which applies to individuals recognized by a host country as having the rights and obligations of nationals.

The court affirmed the Immigration and Refugee Board’s (IRB) decision that Article 1E applied, finding the Minister had established Nepete’s status as a permanent resident of the Czech Republic based on a letter from the Czech Consulate.
The court clarified that the burden then shifted to Nepete to demonstrate he *did not* enjoy the rights and obligations of Czech nationals, specifically the ability to re-enter the country.

The court acknowledged Nepete’s re-entry visa had expired, but held that the lack of an *automatic* right of re-entry did not negate his status as someone recognized as having rights akin to a national, citing precedent (specifically *[Case name suppressed]* and *[Case name suppressed]*) where similar situations were upheld.
The court emphasized that the Czech Republic allowed Nepete to *apply* for a re-entry visa, and this possibility was sufficient to trigger Article 1E, even if not a guaranteed right.
The court upheld the IRB’s finding that Nepete failed to demonstrate he would be denied a re-entry visa, and therefore did not meet his burden of proving he lacked the rights of a Czech national.

Even if the court had found Article 1E inapplicable, it stated the application would still fail because the IRB had reasonably determined Nepete did not demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution in the Czech Republic, a matter of evidentiary weighing within the IRB’s jurisdiction.

The court deferred to the IRB’s assessment of the evidence regarding persecution, finding no basis to interfere with the IRB’s conclusion that the incidents Nepete described amounted to discrimination but not persecution.
